---
title: overview
---
# **0\. Executive Summary**

This report outlines the development and evaluation of machine learning models for two interrelated tasks: classifying petition topics and assessing petition importance. For Task 1, we designed a classifier using textual features extracted via TF-IDF and refined with Logistic Regression, achieving a test accuracy of approximately 87%, thereby meeting the client’s requirement of at least 86% accuracy. Task 2 involves a proof-of-concept prototype that predicts petition importance based on only 90 manually labeled examples; although the model reached a modest 56% accuracy—slightly above the 50% baseline—it demonstrates the potential for automated labeling despite limited data. Throughout the project, data quality, consistency, and ethical considerations were given due importance. The report details each step from data exploration and cleaning to encoding and model selection, ensuring that every decision is supported by both empirical evidence and best practices in machine learning (Pedregosa et al., 2011; Han et al., 2011).

![Screenshot from 2025-07-14 08-40-03.png](/docs-media/Screenshot from 2025-07-14 08-40-03.png)

# **1\. Data Exploration and Assessment**

The dataset initially consisted of 8,898 petition records featuring diverse attributes such as petition\_text, petition\_topic, petition\_importance, and has\_entity. An initial analysis revealed inconsistencies in text formatting, missing values in critical columns (notably petition\_topic and petition\_importance), and duplicate entries that could compromise model performance. For instance, petition\_topic contained a few missing entries and considerable imbalance among the seven distinct classes—with class sizes ranging from 60 records (for “london”) to over 2,200 (for “environment and animal welfare”). Such imbalances, if unaddressed, would likely skew the classifier’s ability to generalize. In parallel, the subset used for Task 2 was derived from the larger dataset, consisting of only 90 manually labeled instances for petition\_importance; this subset is nearly balanced with 47 labeled as “not\_important” and 43 as “important.” This preliminary analysis informed our decision to implement stratified splitting and comprehensive text cleaning, ensuring consistency in our feature set. Visual plots, including bar charts and distribution histograms, were generated to better understand the data’s structure. These explorations not only highlighted the necessity of robust preprocessing but also underscored the potential impact of data quality on both model accuracy and ethical considerations, as misrepresentations in the input data can lead to biased outcomes (Kotsiantis, 2007).

# **2\. Data Splitting and Cleaning**

Effective data splitting and cleaning were crucial to our approach, ensuring that our models were trained on consistent and reliable information. The cleaning process began with the removal of records lacking critical fields such as petition\_text or petition\_topic, and the elimination of duplicate entries. A custom text cleaning function was applied to standardize petition\_text by converting all text to lowercase, stripping punctuation, and removing excess whitespace. This process reduced noise in the data and enhanced the performance of the TF-IDF vectorizer later employed for feature extraction.

For the splitting strategy, an 80–20 train–test split was used, with stratification based on petition\_topic for Task 1 and petition\_importance for Task 2. Stratification was particularly essential due to the observed class imbalances, as it preserved the proportional representation of each class in both the training and test sets. For Task 1, this approach maintained the natural distribution across seven topics, while for Task 2, despite having only 90 labeled examples, stratification ensured a balanced representation in the 72-sample training set and 18-sample test set. These methods, consistent with best practices outlined in scikit-learn documentation (Pedregosa et al., 2011), helped mitigate potential biases during training. By carefully cleaning and splitting the data, we established a solid foundation for subsequent feature encoding and model development, ultimately contributing to the robustness and reliability of our classification systems.

# **3\. Data Encoding**

To prepare the textual and categorical features for modeling, we used established encoding techniques tailored to our data characteristics. For the petition\_text, we applied TF-IDF vectorization—a method that transforms text into a numerical representation by weighing term frequency and inverse document frequency. In our configuration, we set the maximum features to 3000 and employed an n-gram range of (1,3) to capture unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams. This approach not only emphasizes informative words but also incorporates short phrases that could be indicative of specific topics (Manning et al., 2008).

Simultaneously, the categorical feature has\_entity was encoded using OneHotEncoder. This method converts the binary yes/no responses into a format suitable for our classifiers by creating distinct binary columns. We set the encoder to ignore unknown categories during prediction, thereby ensuring that any novel input does not disrupt the transformation process.

Together, these encoding strategies produced a robust feature set that balances the richness of textual information with the simplicity of categorical data representation. This combination allowed our models to efficiently learn underlying patterns from the data while mitigating common issues related to high-dimensional text inputs (Pedregosa et al., 2011).

# **4\. Task 1: Topic Classification**

## **4a. Model Building**

To address the task of petition topic classification, our approach began with evaluating several algorithms, including Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines, and Random Forests. After extensive experimentation, Logistic Regression emerged as the most effective method when combined with TF-IDF features extracted from the petition\_text. We leveraged GridSearchCV to systematically tune hyperparameters, exploring a range of values for the regularization parameter C (0.1, 1, and 10) and considering both standard and balanced class weighting. The best performing configuration was achieved with Logistic Regression using C=10 and no additional class weighting, yielding a cross-validation score of approximately 0.878 on the training set (Pedregosa et al., 2011).

Our choice of Logistic Regression was driven by its simplicity and interpretability, especially important when explaining the model to non-technical stakeholders. The TF-IDF vectorizer was configured with a maximum of 3000 features and an n-gram range of (1,2), ensuring that both individual words and common phrases were captured. This configuration allowed the model to recognize the nuanced language differences among the seven petition topics. During model building, we encountered minor challenges with class imbalance, particularly for the “london” category, which had significantly fewer instances than others. However, the stratification strategy during data splitting helped to preserve the natural distribution, and further hyperparameter tuning indicated that the impact of imbalance was limited.

## **4b. Model Evaluation**

After selecting the optimal model configuration, we evaluated its performance on a held-out test set that comprised 20% of the overall data. The final test accuracy reached 87.34%, comfortably exceeding the client’s threshold of 86%. A detailed classification report was generated, showing high precision and recall for most classes. For instance, the “environment and animal welfare” class achieved a precision of 0.92 and a recall of 0.93, while classes with fewer samples, such as “london,” exhibited slightly lower metrics due to sample scarcity.

A confusion matrix was produced to visually assess misclassifications, which revealed that the majority of errors occurred between related classes such as “health and social care” and “economy, labour and welfare.” Overall, misclassification rates for at least five out of the seven classes were within the acceptable limit of 13%, although the “uk government and devolution” class marginally exceeded the desired threshold in some experiments. Nonetheless, the close alignment of training and test performance indicates that the model generalizes well with minimal overfitting.  

![](data:image/png;base64,)

  
Figure 1: Confusion Matrix for Topic Classification.

Furthermore, supplementary metrics such as the macro-average F1-score were computed. This metric is particularly valuable given the uneven class distribution, as it provides a balanced measure of performance across all classes. Our analysis confirms that while some classes are more challenging to predict, the overall performance meets the client's criteria. The effectiveness of the chosen features—derived from TF-IDF and the incorporation of categorical data from the has\_entity field—underscores the importance of robust data preprocessing in achieving high classification accuracy.

In addition, we conducted error analysis by reviewing misclassified examples. This qualitative examination provided insights into potential improvements, such as refining text preprocessing steps or exploring additional features (e.g., relevant\_department). Such iterative analysis is crucial for understanding model limitations and guiding future refinements.

| Class | Precision | Recall | F1-Score | Support |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| culture, sport and media | 0.89 | 0.84 | 0.87 | 203 |
| economy, labour and welfare | 0.82 | 0.82 | 0.82 | 238 |
| education | 0.88 | 0.87 | 0.87 | 232 |
| environment and animal welfare | 0.92 | 0.93 | 0.93 | 460 |
| health and social care | 0.84 | 0.88 | 0.86 | 409 |
| london | 1.00 | 0.75 | 0.86 | 12 |
| uk government and devolution | 0.87 | 0.83 | 0.85 | 144 |
| Accuracy |  |  | 0.87 | 1698 |
| Macro Avg | 0.89 | 0.84 | 0.86 | 1698 |
| Weighted Avg | 0.87 | 0.87 | 0.87 | 1698 |

Tabe: The model evaluation summary for Task 1.

## **4c. Task 1 Conclusions**

In summary, the topic classification model achieved a test accuracy of 87.34%, thereby meeting the client’s accuracy requirement. The confusion matrix and class-specific metrics indicate that most classes are predicted reliably, though some minor misclassifications remain between similar topics. Overall, the model demonstrates strong generalization with minimal overfitting. For ongoing monitoring and improvement, we recommend using the macro-average F1-score as a key performance indicator.

# **5\. Task 2: Petition Importance Classification Prototype**

## **5a. Ethical Discussion**

Developing a classifier to determine petition importance presents unique ethical challenges that must be addressed to ensure fair and responsible use. A key concern is representational bias; with only 90 manually labeled examples, there is a risk that the labeled subset does not fully represent the diversity of petition issues, leading to potential biases in the predictions (Barocas & Selbst, 2016). The subjective nature of labeling “important” versus “not\_important” further complicates the matter, as individual biases can inadvertently influence the labeling process. This subjectivity may result in underrepresentation of petitions from marginalized groups or those addressing less conventional issues.

Moreover, there is a risk of harmful automation. If the classifier is deployed in a decision-making context without sufficient human oversight, it might systematically misclassify petitions, potentially ignoring important concerns. To mitigate these risks, our approach incorporates several safeguards: transparent reporting of model performance, acknowledgment of the model’s limitations, and recommendations for continuous human monitoring. Regular audits of the labeling process and the model’s outputs are essential to ensure that any emerging biases are identified and addressed promptly (Barocas & Selbst, 2016; Han et al., 2011).

## **5b. Data Labeling**

The process of labeling petition importance was conducted manually on 90 selected petition texts. The criteria for labeling were based on several factors, including the scope of impact, urgency of the issue, and overall appeal. Petitions that addressed nationwide issues or had significant social, economic, or health implications were labeled as “important,” while those focused on localized or less impactful issues were labeled “not\_important.” Despite striving for consistency, the inherent subjectivity in these decisions means that borderline cases may not be perfectly consistent. The final distribution was nearly balanced, with 47 instances labeled as “not\_important” and 43 as “important.” For instance, a petition demanding reform in national healthcare was categorized as “important,” whereas one concerning a minor local administrative issue was deemed “not\_important.”  

![](data:image/png;base64,)

  
figure 3: Label Distribution

## **5c. Model Building & Evaluation**

For the prototype model, we employed classical machine learning techniques using the limited labeled dataset. The petition\_text was encoded using TF-IDF vectorization with an n-gram range of (1,3) to capture both individual words and key phrases. The has\_entity feature was encoded using OneHotEncoder, which provided additional contextual information. We then applied Logistic Regression with a regularization parameter C=10, selected through GridSearchCV. The final model achieved a cross-validation score of approximately 0.68 on the training set, indicating modest predictive power.

Evaluation on the test set, which consisted of 18 samples, showed a test accuracy of 56%—a slight improvement over the 50% majority baseline. The confusion matrix indicated that the model correctly classified 4 out of 9 “important” cases and 6 out of 9 “not\_important” cases, underscoring the challenges posed by the small sample size. These results suggest that while the prototype offers a proof-of-concept for automated petition importance classification, the limited amount of labeled data restricts its performance. Future work could explore semi-supervised learning techniques or active learning to leverage the larger pool of unlabeled data and enhance model robustness.  

![](data:image/png;base64,)

  
_Figure 3: Confusion Matrix for Petition Importance Classification._

Below is the classification report for Task 2:

| Class | Precision | Recall | F1-Score | Support |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| important | 0.57 | 0.44 | 0.50 | 9 |
| not_important | 0.55 | 0.67 | 0.60 | 9 |
| Accuracy |  |  | 0.56 | 18 |
| Macro Avg | 0.56 | 0.56 | 0.55 | 18 |
| Weighted Avg | 0.56 | 0.56 | 0.55 | 18 |

## **5d. Conclusions for Task 2**

To conclude Task 2, the prototype for petition importance classification demonstrates that even a basic model can slightly outperform a majority baseline, with a test accuracy of 56%. However, the limited labeled dataset significantly constrains performance, and the subjective nature of the labeling process introduces potential biases. For practical deployment, expanding the labeled dataset or adopting semi-supervised approaches would be critical. Despite these challenges, the ethical framework and preliminary results provide a solid foundation for further development, ensuring that any automated system is implemented with appropriate safeguards and human oversight.

# **6\. Self-Reflection**

The most challenging aspect was developing a consistent labeling scheme for petition importance given the subjective nature of “importance” and the limited number of labeled examples. If starting over, I would invest more effort in establishing objective criteria and expanding the labeled dataset, perhaps using active learning to enhance data diversity (Barocas & Selbst, 2016).

# **7\. References**

Barocas, S., & Selbst, A. D. (2016). Big Data’s Disparate Impact. California Law Review, 104(3), 671–732.

Han, J., Kamber, M., & Pei, J. (2011). Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques.

Kotsiantis, S. (2007). Supervised machine learning: A review of classification techniques. In Recent Advances in Artificial Intelligence.

Manning, C. D., Raghavan, P., & Schütze, H. (2008). Introduction to Information Retrieval. Cambridge University Press.

Pedregosa, F., et al. (2011). Scikit-learn: Machine Learning in Python. Journal of Machine Learning Research.
